title: Is turning in 152 words for a maximum 200-word essay OK? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, I guess it depends on one or more aspects. First of all, I believe that word limits are only put to verify your skill in expressing what you’re asked to write about as precisely and concisely as possible. Secondly, how strict each organization/university is with the word limit depends on the organization/university itself and its standards. Nevertheless, most of the time you should start having concerns when you exceed the limit, not when you write fewer words than the limit. Thirdly, if you believe that you have covered all the aspects of the essay’s topic/question within those 152 words, I believe this won’t cause you any trouble. Lastly, the most important thing is to always ask yourself after finishing every essay whether you have answered the question as fully as possible or not—even if you have written fewer words than are required.

The answer is built into your question; if the MAXIMUM is 200 words, and you've written only 152, why the question? You do know that "maximum" does not mean "exactly," right?Frankly, 200 words doesn't seem like that much to me. The basic "template" for an essay is five paragraphs: 1: Introduction/Exposition, 2, 3, 4: the discussion paragraphs in which you provide support for your premise (discussed in your introduction), then 5: Conclusion.Five paragraphs, 200 words, amounts to 40 words per paragraph, approximately 4 sentences of 10 words each.You'd need a very narrowly defined topic and you'd have to be extremely concise.And you've only written 152 words?

I also think that there is nothing bad in having 152 words since you have not exceeded the stated maximum. All what really matters is whether your essay answers the main question. If you are not sure about the structure or grammar, you may contact the writers from grand-essays.com who can proofread it for you.
What is it about “maximum 200 words” that you don’t understand? Did the instructions say “minimum 200 words,” or “exactly 200 words?”
That seems okay. As long as your essay addresses everything in the instructions. It’s only 50 words shy of the limit.

Generally speaking specifications are that. The minimum requirement for a grading mark. Since you're 48 words shy of the maximum you're fine and have a healthy amount of room to finish off the closing statement.

No. Teachers give a certain number of words to see how you organize writing within requisites. If a writer is told to write a 1000 word story, he has to fill a space. Pretend like you are getting paid for writing an article for a magazine. Your real pay is a grade, I assume.
